Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: A Hybrid Detector Network for Nuclear and Radioactive Threat Detection

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The most compelling problem confronting detection of nuclear material in a large area is the level of manifest uncertainty. Furthermore, detection and localization problems involve nontrivial and nonlinear non-convex optimization often stuck at local minima. This project develops fundamentally new techniques by using cheap detectors for rough detection and localization, placing detectors to expunge local minima, achieving fast distributed localization with reduced communication overheads, simultaneously localizing multiple sources and optimally placing detectors and assisting in their autonomous self-organization.

There is a growing recognition of the inadequacy of current capabilities with respect to nuclear material detection and localization in public events and areas. This project develops an integrated cyber-physical system for public protection against nuclear and radiological threats. Clearly the project addresses a national security issue. If successful, the contribution and results of the project likely open a new framework for detection or monitoring in a large area using a wireless detector network. One of the key aspects of this project is the inter-disciplinary training of our graduate and undergraduate students including female and minority students in the areas of signal processing, statistical methods, modeling and performance analysis. K-12 students are also targeted through the First competition and Project-Lead-The-Way that connects the College of Engineering at the University of Iowa to almost all high school students in Iowa. It is expected that the project will generate enthusiasm and interests in science, mathematics and engineering for high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is well recognized that current capabilities with respect to nuclear material detection and localization in public events and areas are inadquate. The research support by this grant develops an integrated cyber-physical system for public protection against nuclear and radiological threats.

The main technical contributions of the research can be summaried into the following areas:

(1)   Nuclear background in an urban setting is known to be a highly fluctuating function of position because of large variability in concentration of naturally occurring radioactive materials.  This makes nuclear threat detection very challenging. An intuitive but justifiable way to detect nuclear material is proposed that is theoretically justified and experimentally validated by the field data.

(2)   Binary sensor network is inexpensive and requires very little communication bandwidth. It is ideal for an inexpensive detection network that can be widely deployed. On the other hand, binary sensors are notoriously unreliable. The research shows however, if the number of sensors in the network is large, accurate and replible results can be obtained. In a sense, accuracy and reliability can be achieved by deploying an  increasing number of cheap sensors. Further, the limit properties when the number is large are derived.

(3) A more interesting question is if binary sensors can be usedd for tracking of movment of nuclear material. The research demostrates that not only binary sensosr can be used for tracking but also only three well placed binary sensors suffices.

(4) Another interesting question is what if the signal propogation mode lis unknown. This happens in nuclear case as well as in many cases. Our research developes a method that can detect source even without knowing signal propagation models. 

Technical contributions are disseminated by conference presenatations and journal paper publications.  

Besides technical contributions, the grant supported 4 graduate students. Two finished their PhD and one finidhed his Master. One is finishing his PhD.  Some results have been incorporated into a new course "Internet of Things". The course has been offered every year since 2015. 

In addition, field data was collected that serves as a test bed for others to use. This is important because nuclear material detection is a national security issue and many people are working on it. Lack of actual field data is an issue in terms of validating theoretical results.
